gmd:metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: SAND_GRAVEL_PITS_ABANDONED_IN is a point shapefile that shows the locations of abandoned sand and gravel pits in Indiana. It is derived from an unpublished memorandum report of the Indiana Geological Survey (IGS): Hasenmueller, W. A., 2001, Preliminary database of abandoned sand and gravel pits, Coal and Industrial Minerals Section Memorandum Report 98, Indiana Geological Survey, Bloomington, 3 p., and a CD-ROM. NOTE: This shapefile includes 2,275 of 2,515 sand and gravel pit locations from the IGS Abandoned Sand and Gravel Pit Database (titled PrelimSdGvDB.mdb) that are located in Indiana and for which the documented location is to the nearest quarter quarter section. The 240 pit locations that were excluded did not have adequate quarter quarter section information that could be processed by Geographix software. The following discussion is derived from Memorandum Report 98: The Microsoft Access 2000 database PrelimSdGvDB.mdb on the enclosed CD contains information about abandoned sand and gravel pits in Indiana. The data contained in this database represents a preliminary stage in a comprehensive compilation of abandoned sand and gravel pit data stored in the files of the Mineral Resources Section of the Indiana Geological Survey (IGS). The data were taken from a single Mineral Resources Section file titled DATA TABULATION CARDS: Sand and Gravel Pits which documents abandoned sand and gravel pits examined by IGS geologists in the late 1940s and early 1950s. Although these data have been assembled into a simple flat-file database they should not be regarded as a final compilation of the above mentioned file nor should they be regarded as a compilation of all abandoned sand and gravel pit information filed in IGS Mineral Resources Section files. The Mineral Resources Section is providing this preliminary database in response to a request from the Energy Resources Section of the IGS.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: SAND_GRAVEL_PITS_ABANDONED_IN was created to provide a preliminary digital shapefile of abandoned sand and gravel pits in Indiana, suitable for use in a GIS.

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: DATA DISCLAIMER This data set was compiled by Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey, using data believed to be accurate; however, a degree of error is inherent in all data. This product is distributed "AS-IS" without warranties of any kind, either expressed or implied, including but not limited to warranties of suitability to a particular purpose or use. No attempt has been made in either the design or production of these data to define the limits or jurisdiction of any federal, state, or local government. These data are intended for use only at the published scale or smaller and are for reference purposes only. They are not to be construed as a legal document or survey instrument. A detailed on-the-ground survey and historical analysis of a single site may differ from these data. gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: This file is available to anyone, but access may be contingent on written request, specific terms relevant to the agency or person making the request, and (or) current freedom of information statutes in the state of Indiana.

gmd:environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: ESRI ArcGIS 8.3 shapefile format, approximately 2.4 Mb.

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: Duplicate features may exist in this data set. Sand and gravel pits which were abandoned and reopened under a new name may be represented more than once in the data set.

This shapefile includes 2,275 of 2,515 sand and gravel pit locations from the IGS Abandoned Sand and Gravel Pit Database (titled "PrelimSdGvDB.mdb") that are located in Indiana and for which the documented location is to the nearest quarter quarter section. The 240 pit locations that were excluded did not have adequate quarter quarter section information that could be processed by Geographix software.
The sand and gravel pit sites included in this shapefile were identified by IGS field geologists or taken from literature sources judged to be reliable by IGS geologists.

Most of the quarry location coordinates were obtained using Geographix Software and a land grid developed by White Star, Inc. (Denver, CO). The locations will be no more precise than the third quarter section, or the number of quarter sections in the field named "Qtr".

Stratigraphic measurements are in feet. Measurements are reported to the nearest 0.1 foot. The precision of the original data varies from measurement to the nearest 0.1 foot to estimate to the nearest 10 feet.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Information about abandoned sand and gravel pits in Indiana was obtained by IGS geologists from literature sources, public records, and visits to sand and gravel pit sites. These data were compiled into a file named "Database of Abandoned Sand and Gravel Pits.txt." The Database of Abandoned Sand and Gravel Pits in Indiana was converted to a Microsoft Access database (referred to as the "Preliminary Abandoned Sand and Gravel Pits Database").

The field Qtr from the SdGvDb table was parsed into two new fields, qtr1 and qtr2. A new field, qtr3, was added to more precisely describe some of the locations, such as "C NW." A text file was then created with locations using the Congressional Land Survey System (section, township, and range); this text file was processed with GES97 software, GeoGraphix, Inc., using a land grid created by White Star Corp. to obtain coordinate locations in UTM Zone 16 NAD27. This data was imported back into PrelimSdGvDB.mdb and joined with the SdGvDb table to create the table SG3. Two queries were created to count the number of locations from the original file and the number of locations that now had coordinate values. A new table, nocoords, was created from the results of these queries. A new Access database, S_G.mdb, was created and the tables SG3 and nocoords were imported into this database.

A Microsoft Access table named "SG3" within the database named "S_G.MDB" was exported as a DBase IV file named "SG3.DBF." SG3.DBF was then added as a table to an ESRI ArcView 3.3 View. The Add Event Theme function was used to add the data to the view, and the Convert to Shapefile function was used to save the data as a shapefile named "SG3_NAD27.SHP." The shapefile was edited in ESRI ArcView 3.3 to eliminate 240 records for which no UTM values were available. The fields named "Utmx27" and "Utmy27" were then deleted. SG3_NAD27.SHP was then re-projected to UTM Zone 16 NAD83, using the Define Projection Wizard and the Project Wizard of ESRI ArcToolbox 8.3, and the resulting shapefile was named "SAND_GRAVEL_PITS_ABANDONED_IN.SHP."

This metadata was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit) and MP (Metadata Parser) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (United States Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected, except that no values were assigned to "Abscissa_Resolution" and "Ordinate_Resolution."
SAND_GRAVEL_PITS_ABANDONED_IN was extracted from the Preliminary Database of Abandoned Sand and Gravel Pits.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Preliminary Database of Abandoned Sand and Gravel Pits, Coal and Industrial Minerals Section Memorandum Report No. 98.

gmd:maintenanceNote.gco:CharacterString: Metadata was created as or translated to ISO 19139 for inclusion in the Big Ten Academic Alliance Geoportal.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Big Ten Academic Alliance Geospatial Data Project

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Big Ten Academic Alliance Geospatial Data Project
